profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born in Beaufort, Beaufort County, S.C., September 29, 1831; attended the public schools and was graduated from St. John's College, Fordham, N.Y., in 1850; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1854 and commenced practice in Charleston, S.C.; member of the State house of representatives 1858-1866; served in the Civil War as a lieutenant in the Lafayette Artillery; delegate to the Democratic National Conventions in 1872 and 1876; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1874 to the Forty-fourth and in 1876 to the Forty-fifth Congresses; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-sixth Congress (March 4, 1879-March 3, 1881); received credentials as a Member-elect to the Forty-seventh Congress, but died, pending a contest by Edmund W.M. Mackey (which subsequently resulted successfully for the contestant), in Charleston, S.C., April 26, 1881; interment in St. Lawrence Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: O'Connor, Michael Patrick. The life and letters of M. P. O'Connor. New York: Dempsey & Carroll, 1893.

United States. Congress (47th, 1st session : 1881-1882). Memorial addresses on the life and character of Michael P. O'Connor (a Representative from South Carolina), delivered in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. Forty-seventh Congress, first session. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1882.

researchRecord.name: 1854-1880, 2 volumes.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains a ledger, 1854-1870, and a letterpress book, 1877-1880, of M. P. O'Connor, an attorney.

recordLocation.name: Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: 1879, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Michael Patrick O'Connor to Henry Storm written on April 15, 1879. Pertaining to terms served in Legislature, "the last Legislature to which I was elected...met for the last time at Greenville in Apr. 1865."
